items.title: Denmark, US fundamentally disagree over Greenland's future
items.description: The United States and Denmark continue to disagree over the future of Greenland after high-level talks are held at the White House amid ongoing threats from President Donald Trump threatening to seize the semi-autonomous Danish territory for national security reasons.

items.title: Doctors urge caution as injuries from ladder and roof falls rise
items.description: Thousands of people present to Australian hospitals each year for ladder and roof falls, with doctors urging caution — particularly for ageing Australians.

items.title: Islamic group in government's sights says it 'cannot be banned'
items.description: Controversial group Hizb ut-Tahrir says the government "cannot ban" its ideas despite its members facing the threat of jail time under new hate speech laws to go before parliament.

items.title: Rental market growth stalls, as tenants hit limit of what they can pay
items.description: Australia's rental market is "starting to rebalance" with prices flat in some capital cities but affordability remains a concern, according to Domain, which says an annual salary of $100,000 is needed to live comfortably.

items.title: Best rain in months brings flood threat to eastern and northern Australia
items.description: Severe thunderstorms and flooding rain are expected to ease the short-term fire threat, while Queensland continues to be drenched from ex-Tropical Cyclone Koji.

items.title: A message to Donald Trump from inside Iran: 'Rescue us from this situation'
items.description: From inside Iran, a defiant voice bravely breaks through the internet blackout to detail the horrors she has witnessed and to tell the president of the United States "the people are waiting for America to intervene".

items.title: A few extra minutes of exercise and sleep may help you live a year longer
items.description: Two new studies have found that small improvements in day-to-day life can have substantial impacts on life expectancy.

items.title: Rare alignment to offer glimpse of interstellar comet's dust

featured_image.name: We're trying to get a 'direct sample' from Comet 3I/ATLAS's ...

items.description:
Astronomers are preparing for an unprecedented observational window when interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS aligns with the Sun-Earth axis on January 22, 2026, offering scientists what researchers describe as a once-in-decades opportunity to study pristine material from another star system.

A new research paper published this week by Harvard astrophysicist Avi Loeb and Italian astronomer Mauro Barbieri of Italy's National Institute for Astrophysics (INAF) details how the rare geometric alignment will enable measurements of the comet's dust composition that have never been possible with interstellar visitors.[1][2]

items.title: Russia's allies question Moscow's support as Ukraine war drains resources

featured_image.name: 'Closing his eyes': Why is Russia's Putin quiet on US abduction of ...

items.description:
Russia’s closest partners from Venezuela to Iran and Cuba are reassessing what Moscow’s backing is worth, after a series of crises in which Vladimir Putin’s government appeared either unable—or unwilling—to step in.

The clearest warning sign has come in Venezuela, where the U.S. operation that captured President Nicolás Maduro on Jan. 3 has exposed gaps in the security ecosystem Caracas built with Russian and Cuban help—and showcased the limits of Russia’s power projection as it remains fixated on Ukraine.[1][2][3]

items.title: Greens deal in play as Coalition backs off Labor's hate and gun reforms
items.description: Liberals are backing away from a push to tackle antisemitism with stronger racial hatred laws, with some senior figures in the party also voicing freedom of speech concerns.

items.title: Firefighters gain ground across Victoria as damage toll rises
items.description: More than 228 homes have been confirmed destroyed by bushfires across Victoria, with authorities warning the total is likely to rise.

items.title: Starlink now free in Iran as France weighs satellite aid

featured_image.name: Trump seeks help from Musk's Starlink to break Iran internet ...

items.description:
SpaceX's Starlink satellite internet service is now available for free in Iran, activists confirmed Wednesday, as France announced it is exploring sending Eutelsat terminals to the country to help citizens circumvent a communications blackout during the deadliest protests in the Islamic Republic in decades.

The dual initiatives represent an international effort to restore information flows as the death toll from Iran's brutal crackdown on demonstrators has surpassed 2,500, according to the U.S.-based Human Rights Activists News Agency (HRANA), which reported at least 2,571 dead as of early Wednesday.[1][2]

items.title: Webb telescope's mysterious 'little red dots' are young black holes

featured_image.name: Are the JWST's Little Red Dots actually supermassive black ...

items.description:
Since the James Webb Space Telescope began operations in late 2021, one of its most perplexing discoveries has been hundreds of tiny, unexplained red points scattered throughout images of the early universe. Now, researchers from the University of Copenhagen have cracked the mystery: these "little red dots" are young supermassive black holes hidden within dense cocoons of ionized gas.

The findings, published Wednesday in Nature, reveal that these enigmatic objects are far less massive than scientists initially believed—about 100 times smaller—yet still weigh up to 10 million times the mass of our Sun.[1][2]

items.title: Half the world's major river deltas sink faster than seas rise

featured_image.name: Sinking river deltas put millions at risk of flooding | New ...

items.description:
Nearly half of the world's largest river deltas, including the Nile, Ganges, and Mekong, are sinking faster than global sea levels are rising, according to new research published Wednesday in Nature. The study warns that more than 236 million people face heightened flooding risk as human-caused land subsidence emerges as the dominant threat to these coastal regions.

The research, led by scientists at the University of California, Irvine and Virginia Tech, provides the first high-resolution, delta-wide assessment of elevation loss across 40 major river deltas spanning five continents. Using satellite radar data collected between 2014 and 2023, the team found that 18 of those deltas are experiencing average annual subsidence rates that exceed the current global sea-level rise rate of about 4 millimeters per year.[1][2][3]

items.title: Musk denies Grok generated explicit images of minors
items.description:
Elon Musk said on Wednesday he was unaware of any explicit images of minors generated by his xAI chatbot Grok, even as global regulatory pressure against the AI tool reached a fever pitch with government investigations spanning three continents.

"I not aware of any naked underage images generated by Grok. Literally zero," Musk wrote in a post on X, his social media platform. "Obviously, Grok does not spontaneously generate images, it does so only according to user requests. When asked to generate images, it will refuse to produce anything illegal, as the operating principle for Grok is to obey the laws of the given country or state."[1][2][3]

The remarks come as xAI faces investigations from California Attorney General Rob Bonta, the UK communications regulator Ofcom, and mounting calls from U.S. lawmakers to remove Grok from app stores operated by Apple and Google.

items.title: AI triples scientist output but shrinks research scope, study finds

featured_image.name: AI and science: what 1,600 researchers think

items.description:
Artificial intelligence has created a paradox in science: tools that supercharge individual researchers are simultaneously shrinking the collective scope of scientific exploration, according to a major study published in Nature.

The research, conducted by James Evans of the University of Chicago and colleagues, analyzed more than 41 million research papers spanning biology, medicine, chemistry, physics, materials science, and geology from 1980 to 2025. The findings reveal that scientists who adopt AI publish 3.02 times as many papers and receive nearly five times as many citations as their peers who do not use AI. They also reach leadership positions about 1.5 years earlier.[1][2]

Yet this individual success comes at a cost to the broader scientific enterprise. AI-driven research covers 4.6% less topical territory than conventional studies and spawns 22% less engagement between papers.[2][1]

items.title: Denmark deploys troops to Greenland as officials meet at White House

featured_image.name: Greenland Live: Denmark Deploys Advance Troops as Trump Threatens Takeover

items.description:
Denmark announced on Wednesday it is deploying military units and equipment to Greenland starting immediately, as officials from Copenhagen and Nuuk arrived at the White House for high-stakes talks over President Donald Trump's escalating demands to acquire the Arctic territory.

"The Danish armed forces are, from today, deploying capabilities and units related to exercise activities. In the period ahead, this will result in an increased military presence in and around Greenland, comprising aircraft, vessels and soldiers, including from NATO allies," the Danish Defense Ministry said in a statement.[1][2]

items.title: FBI raids home and seizes devices of Washington Post journalist
items.description: The reporter had previously reported on the Trump administration's efforts to fire hundreds of thousands of federal workers.

items.title: Iran's judiciary chief vows swift trials and executions for protesters

featured_image.name: Live updates: Iran protests death toll soars, fears of Erfan ...

items.description:
Iran's chief of judiciary announced on Wednesday that rapid trials and possible executions will proceed for thousands of protesters detained during nationwide demonstrations, directly challenging President Donald Trump's warning that the United States would take "very strong action" if the Islamic Republic begins hanging dissidents.

Gholamhossein Mohseni-Ejei made the statement in a video broadcast by Iranian state television, emphasizing urgency: "If we want to do a job, we should do it now. If we want to do something, we have to do it quickly. If it becomes late, two months, three months later, it doesn't have the same effect."[1][2][3]

The announcement came as human rights organizations reported that Erfan Soltani, a 26-year-old clothing seller from Fardis near Tehran, was scheduled to become the first protester executed in connection with the unrest. His fate remained uncertain Wednesday, with the Hengaw Organization for Human Rights unable to confirm whether the execution had been carried out amid Iran's ongoing communications blackout.[4][5]

items.title: Chinese scientists develop 'soggy sand' battery that lasts 1,700 cycles

featured_image.name: The Surprising Battery Discovery No One Saw Coming

items.description:
Scientists at the Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics (DICP) of the Chinese Academy of Sciences have developed a novel "soggy sand" electrolyte that enables aqueous zinc metal batteries to achieve 1,700 charge-discharge cycles while operating at temperatures up to 140°C—a breakthrough that could accelerate the shift away from lithium-ion technology for grid-scale energy storage.

The research, published in Nature Communications in December 2025, addresses one of the most persistent challenges facing aqueous zinc batteries: their tendency to fail under thermal stress due to uncontrollable side reactions in traditional water-based electrolytes above 60°C.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: President Trump Announces U.S. Military Airstrike in Venezuela
items.description: President Trump states the U.S. military conducted its first known airstrike inside Venezuela targeting a dock where drugs were allegedly loaded onto boats[1][2][4].

items.title: Trump Meets Netanyahu at Mar-a-Lago for Gaza Ceasefire Phase Two Talks
items.description: President Trump met with Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu to discuss advancing phase two of the Gaza ceasefire, including reconstruction and responses to Iran[1][4].

items.title: Feds Launch Massive Taxpayer Fraud Probe in Minnesota After Viral Video
items.description: Federal agencies including DHS, FBI, and ICE investigate $110 million in suspected fraud at Minnesota child care centers following a viral YouTube video[3].

items.title: Americans Express Widespread Opposition to AI Data Centers
items.description: Public backlash against AI infrastructure data centers grows, with protests and demands for bans influencing Democratic Party strategies for future elections[3].

items.title: Elon Musk's Humanoid Robot Vision: China Poised to Lead Production
items.description: China prioritizes humanoid robots in tech race with U.S., ramping up production while warning of industry bubble and potential bottlenecks[3].

items.title: Trump-Putin Call Amid Ukraine-Russia Tensions Over Peace Plan
items.description: President Trump spoke with Putin amid ongoing Ukraine conflict, with Russia reevaluating peace plan tenets after Ukrainian denials[1].

items.title: Democratic Gubernatorial Candidates in Wisconsin Focus on Inflation and Trump
items.description: Seven Democrats vying for Wisconsin governor blame economic issues on Trump and emphasize affordability ahead of 2026 primary[3].
